title: Specially crafted doughnuts raise money for cancer charity
text:
WEST YARMOUTH, Mass. (AP) - Talk about sweet charity.

All this month Old King’s Coffeehouse on Route 28 is donating the proceeds from sales of specially crafted pink iced doughnuts to a local nonprofit organization that helps cancer patients and survivors.

With their rounded shapes and caramel tips, the doughnuts look so much like women’s breasts that customers have taken to calling them “booby” doughnuts.

The eye-catching look is intentional, said Mark Corliss, who opened Old King’s Coffeehouse with his wife, Kate Corliss, in June.

“You need something to help attract attention,” said Mark, who also owns Spilt Milk Tattoo in Hyannis.

“People take pictures,” he said. “People have had a blast with it.”

So far this month the coffeehouse has sold 2,050 of the pink doughnuts priced at $3 apiece, said Kate, who manages the coffeehouse.

The fundraiser for the Cape Wellness Collaborative ends Thursday, she said.

The “booby doughnuts” pay tribute to breast cancer patients and survivors who make up a sizable portion of the collaborative’s clientele.

“All of us at the CWC are so grateful for the booby doughnuts,” said Harwich musician Sarah Swain, who founded the collaborative in 2014.

The nonprofit organization provides a variety of wellness services including massage, acupuncture and nutrition counseling to people going through or recovering from all types of cancer treatment, including prophylactic surgery.

“I lost my mother to ovarian cancer, my grandmother to breast cancer, and I myself have undergone a bilateral mastectomy after going (through) genetic counseling and finding out that I carry a high-risk gene,” Swain said via email.

The doughnut sale is not only raising awareness about breast cancer but also is “helping us get the word out to our community that there is a local cancer charity where all of their dollars will stay here on Cape Cod,” Swain said.

The collaborative offers “services insurance companies don’t cover that can really help people,” Mark said.

He’s no stranger to helping people with cancer, regularly volunteering his time to tattoo realistic-looking nipples for women who have had breast reconstruction surgery after mastectomies.

In the last six years, the number of tattooed sets has come to about 700, Mark said.

“Working with so many breast cancer patients over the years has inspired him to do this fundraiser,” Swain said. “He is an amazing community connector.”

The pink doughnut was Mark’s idea, said Kate, who has a background in the restaurant business.

“Then he gave me the creative freedom to run with it,” she said.

The doughnut comes with a strawberry jam filling, pink French vanilla glaze and caramel chip in the middle.

More than 12 local businesses, including Shoreline Pools, Whalen Restoration Services and Old Yarmouth Inn, have either purchased doughnuts or made a monetary contribution to the Cape Wellness Collaborative, Mark said.

Linda Basinsky, shift supervisor at Old King’s Coffeehouse, said she brought the doughnuts to a mammography appointment at the Cuda Women’s Center on Wilkens Lane in Hyannis.

“It was kind of like a ‘thank you’ for what they do,” Basinsky said.

Some people blush when they hear someone order a “booby doughnut,” Basinsky said.

But that was not the case with a police officer who recently placed an order, said fellow shift supervisor Meaghan Golden.

“He ordered ‘a medium dark roast and one booby doughnut,’” Golden said. He said it was to “support the cause.”
